column4: hello... i just transfered my ubuntu install to another harddrive but now when i boot it says "grub harddisk failure".  What i did (in order) was a) use cpio to make a direct copy of hd a to hd b b) installed grub on the other hd by doing "grub-install /dev/sdb" c) changed the uuid's in /etc/fstab and /boot/grub/menu.lst.  did i miss anything?  any ideas?
unique approach, but why not just dd the drive? i haven't tried it precisely your way but it'd "seem" that you did what i would have done...harddisk failure is all it says?
i didn't dd because the drives are different (one is 300GB the other is 1.5TB)... and all it says it HD failure right before getting to the menu, nothing else
yeah but you could dd then expand the partition to take up the extra space
tis what i did with my 160 to 500gb drive in the laptop
i had thought about that... but in the end it's just as far out there as my approach! the UUID's would have had to be modified anyways right?
actually come to thnk of it i didn't mod my uuid's
strange... i was under the impression that UUID depended on the actual HD not the any modifiable data
try specifying the /dev instead of using uuid's
iirc i just went from a gutsy install, did the dd/resize then upgraded to hardy then intrepid and that was it
i just may do that... luckily i still have the original
